Award.AwardTitle: Digitization TCN: Collaborative Research: Documenting marine biodiversity through Digitization of Invertebrate collections (DigIn)
Award.AbstractNarration:
For two centuries, America has amassed an unparalleled collection of specimens from exploring the world's oceans. They were pulled up with nets, scooped up from seabeds with grabs, and hand-collected by divers, all contributing to a library of biodiversity that captures the state of life in the ocean - year after year, decade after decade. The broadest evolutionary scope of those collections is in the marine invertebrates, animals without backbones - sea stars, corals, worms, jellyfish, crabs, and thousands of other animals. That library of preserved marine invertebrates is our essential guide to the diversity of ocean life across the globe. And because they encapsulate data from the moment they were picked up, these institutional collections also act as a time machine, letting us use the past to understand how our present will become the future. But there is a problem - vast numbers of these specimens are essentially invisible outside of a tiny community of museum specialists. The only record of these specimens' existence is on labels enclosed in the jars with the preserved animals or in paper logbooks on a shelf. These specimens will remain nearly undiscoverable on museum shelves until their core descriptive information is made digitally available. Therefore, this project will create public digital records for over 7.5 million specimens from our nation's legacy of marine exploration, thereby making the immense investment in the specimens' acquisition available to 21st Century biodiversity and ecosystems research. Because these specimens provide a visible and tangible window into our oceans' enchanting biodiversity, this project will involve STEM educators and student educators in the digitization effort, so that they will be able to reflect their science experiences directly back to the classroom. The public will be involved virtually, by contributing transcription of specimen label data.

Digitization of alcohol-preserved marine specimens has never been carried out on this scale. A major challenge lies in the location of the data: written, typed, or printed on labels in the jars with the specimens. In many cases, that will require opening the jar, extracting the label, and either transcribing it directly or photographing it for later transcription - for hundreds of thousands of jars. The immediate participants in this program will digitize most or all of the marine invertebrate collections at nineteen institutions across the country, more than doubling the number of digital records for marine invertebrates in the U.S. All data will be publicly available through existing data portals, including iDigBio.org, using standardized data formats, thereby dramatically enhancing the accessibility of biodiversity data for comprehensive, systems-based analysis of ocean ecosystems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum (BPBM) successfully completed its objectives for the National Science Foundation grant titled: Digitization TCN: Collaborative Research: Documenting marine biodiversity through Digitization of Invertebrate collections (DigIn).  This project was a collaborative digitization grant involving 19 United States collections and focused on marine invertebrates. Prior to this effort, there were no compilations of US marine fauna. 

The goal of the DigIn TCN was to enhance the availability of accurate marine biodiversity data by providing online access to the nation’s marine invertebrate collections. The project planned to digitize over 7.5 million marine invertebrate specimens--equating to roughly 835,000 specimen lots--thereby doubling the quantity of specimen information available online from non-federal collections.

Bishop Museum contributed 6,695 new specimen records, and mobilized over 6,000 specimen images, including ones newly generated, surpassing both digitization goals. In addition, 23,599 specimen records were updated with additional taxonomic and/or geographic information. As a result of having this large amount of specimen information accessible and online, there has been a notable increase in efficiency with collection and research activities, including checklist updates, new species descriptions, and geographic range expansions/adjustments for Hawaiian (and tropical Pacific) marine fauna.

This massive effort created the first marine invertebrate digitization network focused on extant marine organisms, one of the most significant outcomes which will continue to grow and evolve after the end of the project. Bishop Museum staff, as part of the DigIn group, contributed several social media posts on the Slack Channel about marine invertebrates as well as highlights on staff and volunteers working on the project.

In addition to the digitization work, we were able to hire a new marine invertebrate technician who performed most of the work on this project including digitization, imaging, and educational outreach. The DigIn project was also featured during several museum behind-the-scenes tours and at outreach events including the annual Science and Sustainability Festival held every year near Earth Day. A link to the DigIn webpage is maintained on the Bishop Museum website.

At Bishop Museum, this project also resulted in the streamlining of several collections procedures and decreased the amount of wear and tear on the specimens overall. We were able to 1) develop a permanent specimen imaging station, 2) link specimen records between our institution and partner institutions (when split for research), 3) find missing metadata needed for some of our older uncataloged specimens, and 4) close out old loan transactions.

The results of our digitization efforts have been made available to researchers and the public. The specimen data and metadata for images are available through the Museum’s IPT server and are accessible via iDigBio and other data aggregators. Digitized images are accessible through the Museum data server.

The new information resources that resulted from this project can be used to better understand the geographic distributions of marine organisms and the marine biodiversity in the United States waters, fill the large taxonomic holes in information about underrepresented marine invertebrate groups, track the distribution and spread of invasive species, and help address large gaps in our understanding of the marine biome. The mobilization of this massive amount of biological information nationwide and the instant availability to scientists and resource managers through data aggregators like iDigBio and GBIF can highlight significant changes that have occurred over time in the ocean and can provide essential information about how best to deal with problematic environmental marine issues like coral bleaching, marine debris, and the rise in ocean temperature.
